From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: punkt

German

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • Punktum (obsolete, except as an interjection)
  • Punct, Punctum (obsolete)

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German punct, Late Latin pūnctus. Doublet of bunt.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /pʊŋ(k)t/, [pʊŋkt], [pʊŋt]
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)

Noun

[edit]

Punkt m (strong, genitive Punktes or Punkts, plural Punkte, diminutive Pünktchen n or Pünktlein n)

  1. dot (marking an abbreviation)
  2. full stop, period (indicating end of sentence)
  3. point
  4. spot
  5. item (on a list)
  6. (in front of a time) sharp; exactly
    um Punkt 9 Uhr. ― at 9 o'clock sharp

Declension

[edit]
Declension of Punkt [masculine, strong]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative ein der Punkt die Punkte
genitive eines des Punktes, Punkts der Punkte
dative einem dem Punkt, Punkte1 den Punkten
accusative einen den Punkt die Punkte

1Now rare, see notes.

Synonyms

[edit]
  • (abbreviation mark): Abkürzungspunkt
  • (end of sentence): Satzendungspunkt
  • (decimal point): Dezimalpunkt
  • (item on a list): Listenpunkt

Hunsrik

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈpʰuŋkt/
  • Rhymes: -uŋkt
  • Syllabification: Punkt

Noun

[edit]

Punkt m (plural Punkt)

  1. dot

Further reading

[edit]
  • Boll, Piter Kehoma (2021), “Punkt”, in Dicionário Hunsriqueano Riograndense–Português, 3rd edition (overall work in Portuguese), Ivoti: Riograndenser Hunsrickisch

Luxembourgish

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Latin punctus

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /pʊŋkt/

Noun

[edit]

Punkt m (plural Punkten)

  1. point, dot

Plautdietsch

[edit]

Noun

[edit]

Punkt m (plural Punkta)

  1. dot, point, jot
  2. period
